messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 18, 2016 - May 24, 2016,Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 18, 2016 - May 24, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-05-25T17:58:33Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-05-18T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-05-24T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160525-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2016-05-21T06:00Z-09:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 on 2016-05-21.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-05-19T17:00Z     ~550            C               148/-2                15                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-05-25T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-05-31T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions present in the solar disk, especially the active regions on the far side, that are capable of producing solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to become elevated by 2016-05-27 due to an anticipated arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 11, 2016 - May 17, 2016,Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 11, 2016 - May 17, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-05-18T20:54:28Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-05-11T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-05-17T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160518-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period.  There were 3 C-type CMEs and 1 O-type CME (see details below).   Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that the CME starting on 2016-05-15T15:36Z may impact Dawn (glancing blow) around 2016-05-26T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notifications 20160515-AL-001, 20160515-AL-002, 20160515-AL-003).  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest values of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2016-05-15T15:00Z-18:00Z and 2016-05-17T06:00Z-09:00Z.  These periods of minor elevated geomagnetic activity were associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 on 2016-05-14.  The highest value of solar wind speed reached 585 km/s on 2016-05-17.   

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt was above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period on 2016-05-11.  GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux was significantly elevated, reaching values of 162,000 pfu on 2016-05-11T17:55Z and it remained above the threshold for several days until 2016-05-13.  This elevation of the energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 on 2016-05-08 (see notifications 20160509-AL-002 and 20160511-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES were slightly elevated on 2016-05-15 due to the coronal mass ejection that started on 2016-05-15T15:36Z, but remained below the threshold of 10 pfu for the entire reporting period.  The 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-05-11T03:24Z     ~700            C                44/22                20                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-05-11T11:24Z     ~688            C                93/38                11                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-05-14T03:12Z     ~535            C               -92/-13               19                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-05-15T15:36Z     ~1198           O                68/17                36                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-05-18T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-05-24T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are several active regions present in the solar disk, especially the active regions on the far side, that are capable of producing solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to become elevated by 2016-05-20 due to an anticipated arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (Dawn),Space Weather Notification - CME update (Dawn)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-05-15T21:51:17Z
## Message ID: 20160515-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Update on CME with ID 2016-05-15T15:36:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20160515-AL-002).  Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Dawn (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Dawn at 2016-05-26T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).  Please note that the this predicted arrival time has been revised from 2016-05-27T00:00Z listed in Notification 20160515-AL-002.


CME parameters are (O-type):

Start time of the event: 2016-05-15T15:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~1198 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 36 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 68/17 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-05-15T15:36:00-CME-001


Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-05-15T15:36:00-CME-001):

(a) 2 AU outer boundary

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160515_185400_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif

(b) 5.5 AU outer boundary
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160515_185400_5.5_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160515_185400_5.5_anim.tim-vel.gif

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME,Space Weather Notification - CME
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-05-15T18:59:58Z
## Message ID: 20160515-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

O-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-05-15T15:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~1190 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 36 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 68/17 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

NASA spacecraft near Earth and Mars can be affected. There is a possibility for a solar energetic particle event.  Updates on this event will be provided when available. 

Activity ID: 2016-05-15T15:36:00-CME-001

## Notes:

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-05-14T03:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~535 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 19 deg.

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Spitzer.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Spitzer at 2016-05-17T06:26Z (plus minus 7 hours).

S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 04, 2016 - May 10, 2016,Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 04, 2016 - May 10, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-05-11T19:59:28Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-05-04T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-05-10T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160511-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at strong levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=7 for the reporting period.  Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 7 (strong) during the synoptic periods of 2016-05-08T03:00Z-06:00Z and 2016-05-09T00:00Z-03:00Z. This strong geomagnetic storm was associated with the arrival detected by ACE at L1 of a coronal hole high speed stream on 2016-05-08 (see notifications 20160508-AL-001, 20160508-AL-002, 20160508-AL-003).  Solar wind speed reached values of ~766 km/s on 2016-05-09.  

A possible arrival was detected by the STEREO Ahead magnetic field and plasma data on 2016-05-04T06:00Z. The arrival could be associated with a filament eruption from the far side near an active region seen in STEREO Ahead EUVI images near N30W60.  Alternatively, it could be related to an eruption close to the disk center observed from STEREO A with an associated CME starting at 2016-04-30T08:24Z.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu.  GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux was above 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-05-09T15:50Z. This elevation has continued for several days (see notifications 20160509-AL-001, 20160509-AL-002 and 20160511-AL-001) and had reached values of 186,000 pfu on 2016-05-10.  This significantly elevated electron flux is associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated electron fluxes in the outer radiation belt.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-05-10T21:17Z     ~674            C               -85/15                12                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-05-11T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-05-17T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are several active regions present in the solar disk, especially the active regions on the far side, that are capable of producing solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to remain low for the upcoming reporting period.

ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement,Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-05-11T15:35:28Z
## Message ID: 20160511-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is currently 1.4*10^5 pfu. This is an ongoing event that started at 2016-05-09T15:50Z and is related to the high speed stream starting at 2016-05-08T01:21Z (see Activity ID 2016-05-09T15:50:00-RBE-001 and Message ID: 20160509-AL-002).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-05-11T14:55:00-RBE-001.

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm,Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-05-08T13:06:48Z
## Message ID: 20160508-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Intensifying space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 7 (strong) during the synoptic period 2016-05-08T03:00Z to 2016-05-08T06:00Z. 

The storm is caused by a negative polarity coronal hole high speed stream (CH HSS) with ID 2016-05-08T01:21:00-HSS-001.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-05-08T00:00:00-GST-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 27, 2016 - May 03, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-05-04T20:36:19Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-04-27T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-05-03T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160504-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-05-02T03:00Z to 2016-05-02T06:00Z. This increase in geomagnetic activity was possibly caused by the arrival detected by ACE at L1 of a coronal hole high speed stream starting around 2016-05-01 with a possible combined arrival of several slow speed (<500 km/s) CMEs originating from the active region 12535 starting on 2016-04-28 (see notifications 20160429-AL-001, 20160502-AL-001, and 20160502-AL-002). The highest value of solar wind speed reached 636 km/s on 206-05-03.  

An arrival was detected by the STEREO Ahead magnetic field and plasma data on 2016-04-27T09:00Z of the CMEs that started on 2016-04-24T23:36Z and 2016-04-25T05:12Z (see notification 20160425-AL-001).  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period, but have been slightly elevated at the end of the reporting period due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-05-04T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-05-10T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are several active regions present in the solar disk, especially the active regions 12539 and 12541, that are capable of producing solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is also expected to slightly increase due to the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2016-05-07.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-05-02T12:16:30Z
## Message ID: 20160502-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-05-02T03:00Z to 2016-05-02T06:00Z. 

The storm was possibly caused by a high speed stream starting around 2016-05-01 with a possible combined arrival of the CMEs from 2016-04-28 (see notification 20160429-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-05-02T03:00:00-GST-001.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.
